Literature Review: The field of computational chemistry has made significant strides in recent years, particularly in the area of reaction prediction and discovery. The ability to accurately predict chemical reactions and their outcomes is of paramount importance in various fields, including drug discovery, materials science, and organic synthesis. This literature review focuses on the development and application of computational methods for reaction discovery, with a particular emphasis on the artificial force induced reaction (AFIR) method and its integration with kinetic simulations.The prediction of chemical reactions has traditionally relied on a two-step approach: first, generating a reaction path network, and then performing kinetic simulations based on this network. However, this approach has limitations, particularly when dealing with complex reaction systems. The combinatorial explosion of possible reaction patterns can make it computationally expensive and time-consuming to explore all potential pathways.To address these challenges, researchers have developed various computational methods for reaction prediction. One such method is the artificial force induced reaction (AFIR) method, introduced by Maeda et al. (2013). The AFIR method uses artificial forces to efficiently explore reaction pathways on potential energy surfaces, allowing for the discovery of both known and unknown reaction mechanisms.The integration of the AFIR method with kinetic simulations has been a significant development in the field. Ohno and Maeda (2019) proposed a method combining AFIR with the rate constant matrix contraction (RCMC) method, enabling on-the-fly kinetic simulations that directly discover chemical reactions and their product yields. This approach addresses the limitations of the conventional two-step method by narrowing the search space based on kinetic analysis of the reaction path network.The AFIR method has been successfully applied to various chemical systems. For instance, Hatanaka et al. (2017) used AFIR to study the mechanism of the Ugi reaction, a multicomponent reaction widely used in organic synthesis. Their study revealed previously unknown reaction pathways and intermediates, demonstrating the power of computational methods in elucidating complex reaction mechanisms.In addition to the AFIR method, other computational approaches have been developed for reaction prediction. Coley et al. (2017) introduced a machine learning-based approach for predicting the outcomes of organic reactions. Their method uses neural networks trained on large datasets of known reactions to predict the products of new reactions. While this approach has shown promise, it is limited by the availability and quality of training data.Another important aspect of reaction prediction is the accurate calculation of reaction rates. Grambow et al. (2018) developed an automated approach for calculating reaction rates using transition state theory. Their method combines automated reaction path finding with high-level electronic structure calculations to provide accurate rate constants for complex reaction networks.The application of these computational methods to real-world problems has been demonstrated in various studies. For example, Zimmerman (2013) used automated reaction prediction methods to discover new pathways for the synthesis of organic molecules. This work highlighted the potential of computational methods to accelerate the discovery of novel synthetic routes in organic chemistry.While significant progress has been made in the field of computational reaction prediction, challenges remain. One major challenge is the accurate description of solvent effects, which can significantly influence reaction outcomes. Plata and Singleton (2015) addressed this issue by developing a method for including explicit solvent molecules in transition state calculations, improving the accuracy of reaction predictions in solution.Another challenge is the prediction of stereochemistry in organic reactions. Peng et al. (2014) developed a computational method for predicting the stereochemical outcomes of organic reactions, demonstrating the potential of computational approaches to address this important aspect of reaction prediction.The integration of quantum chemical calculations with machine learning approaches represents a promising direction for future research. Gao et al. (2020) demonstrated the use of machine learning models to accelerate quantum chemical calculations, potentially enabling the exploration of larger and more complex reaction systems.In conclusion, the field of computational reaction discovery has made significant progress in recent years, with methods such as AFIR and its integration with kinetic simulations showing great promise. These approaches have the potential to revolutionize our understanding of chemical reactivity and accelerate the discovery of new reactions and synthetic pathways. However, challenges remain, particularly in accurately describing solvent effects and predicting stereochemistry. Future research directions, including the integration of quantum chemical calculations with machine learning approaches, hold the promise of further advancing the field of ab initio reaction discovery.
